@bolkedebruin I believe we put in a PR to fix the issues, and we also switched over to rabbitmq as a broker which seemed to help as well.

FYI, I had to run the tests twice, the first test run failed although the codebase is exactly the same:
https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/builds/128738523

Seems like there is an issue with the tests, probably a race condition when accessing data from the sqlite backend.

Yes.. travis is flaky. If at least one python 2.7 and one 3.4 test passes, that's good enough for me.

Worth adding a test similar to what you added in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1478?

Also, can you extend the CLI with this feature in a separate PR?
For example `airflow clear <dag_id> <execution_date>` clears a DAG for an execution date. With this PR, there will be a difference between the CLI and the Web experience. 

Similarly, `airflow backfill <dag_id> -m -s <start_date> -e <end_date>` will currently mark tasks success, but https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1430 was also a UI-only change. I would like to see the CLI similarly extended. 

CLI code is in `bin/cli.py`.

Hey guys, here's the JIRA issue. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-79
@jlowin, can you remove the label ?

I'd say this is done via the `airflow pause_dag <dag_id>` & `airflow unpause_dag <dag_id>` CLIs added and released in 1.7.0. It can be called by an external cron. If someone would like to add this functionality into the UI as a separate pause-unpause schedule, we would welcome the PR. I'm closing this issue for now, but it can be reopened as a Jira should such a PR be issued in the future.
+1 @mistercrunch Can you have a look as well and ensure it's all good for you?
I don't understand why the extra has to be shown in the list view as opposed to only in the edit view? I'd rather customize the Flask-Admin templates as little as possible.

Yeah I agree that cron can do the pause / unpause.

The connection pools in Airflow are very nice because they allow for the limitation of the number of connections to be made and are some easy way for us to control the connections. This ask is for a feature that gives that capability within the Airflow UI and system, as I could imagine blackouts could be something that enterprise users might have to deal with (at least I do).

@mistercrunch Doesn't it make sense to view information without having to click "edit"?
 Similarly for the variable list view... why not show the variable value in the list view? Instead, we must click edit to view the variable value, leaving the possibility for unintended changes.

What version is this being pushed out as?

In any case, while waiting for this fix to be released into pypi, putting `stopasgroup=true` in your supervisor config (http://supervisord.org/configuration.html) should do the trick, no? It seemed to work for me for both the scheduler and the webserver...

link: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-64

@mistercrunch the idea origins from our use cases that we'd have multiple ad-hoc dag runs triggered externally with different configurations, to show `conf` for the task instances helps us to easily see why the dag is shaped as it is. To show `extra` has been helping us identify the missing configurations like `{ "local_infile": true }` which is required by MySQL bulk load while is easily forgot to add.

@r39132 it's definitely a vital switch, I'll add that.
LGTM

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-91 ok
This will not work, as now the necessary commits are not taking place.

LGTM, for reference sake:

set_state is only called when flag_upstream_failed=True this will be always false for are_dependencies_met as it defaults to False. This means no "session.commit()" will be called anymore.

So this will resolve the issue. However the core issue remains and that is that a getter should not change the internal state of the object. That is another issue, so will merge.
LGTM
Should include AIRFLOW-86 in git commit message, though.

@stranbird any updates?

I think this can result in a change of behavior that could create some troubles or slow downs. If many tasks are referencing a params object (which is a common pattern), it will get "rendered" many times. This could result in either unexpected results or inefficiencies / regressions.

It'd be wise to add a new bool param to `BaseOperator` named `render_params`, set to `False` by default and only apply where necessary. I personally wouldn't approve this PR without this safeguard.

If double rendering was an issue (I think with `render_params` it's less of a concern), the DAG object could keep track of object ids (using Python's `id(obj)`) that have been templated and implement some logic in `render_template` to avoid re-rendering objects that have been rendered before.
- entry in `docs/code.rst`

My feeling it's that it's too much custom logic (template override, javascript, ...) to not even avoid one click (you still have to click to view the extras), but just to view that field in the context of the list view.

I'd try to stay vanilla as much as possible. Otherwise it's just more code that we have to support for a very marginally useful feature.
@mistercrunch I see, feel free to close this issue. I am glad to continue working on other features.
Already better. Can you extend the tests to cover this? And make sure to squash your commits.
Let's discuss this further on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-65

> If double rendering was an issue (I think with render_params it's less of a concern), the DAG object could keep track of object ids (using Python's id(obj)) that have been templated and implement some logic in render_template to avoid re-rendering objects that have been rendered before.

Yes, I can see that effectively caching values would avoid the potential slowdown of multiple jinja renders. However, would it not be possible to just store the rendered params on first call within a TI and serve this value of subsequent calls rather than delving into the tracking individual ids walking through the params dict?

Also, I'm confused why you'd say it lives in render_template rather than get_template_context. I wouldn't like to treat it as just another field in template_fields, since you would always want the template_fields to be able to make use of the rendered params. Or are you suggesting a separate block in render_templates?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1489

1. well if it's the same object it's already been rendered in place, so all you want to do it to not re-render it . Maintaining a list of object ids that have been rendered would allow to skip double-rendering
2. get_template_context returns the context used for rendering, it does not render anything. `render_templates` is the method that renders things, so params should be rendered in there along with everything else.
Good catch @r39132 . Could we have a test to cover this?
@NeilHanlon Wondering which airflow version has your fix for this issue? We're also bitten by it recently using airflow 1.6.2 + celery. Thanks!
